awd_titl_txt: P2C2:   Positive Feedback between Dust, Radiation, Precipitation and Temperature as a Driver for Abrupt Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Aerosol feedbacks represent one of the highest uncertainties in the dynamics of the Earth system (IPCC, 2007). Paleoclimate records show significant fluctuations in dust associated with changes in climate. However, the role of dust as a feedback to climate change in the past and into the future remains highly uncertain. The proposed working hypothesis is that a positive feedback between dust, radiation, precipitation and temperature is an important driver for abrupt climate change. Researchers from the University of Miami will focus on two periods of abrupt climate change in the Atlantic: Heinrich Event 1 and the termination of the African Humid Period. These are two periods of abrupt climate change for which the source of the abruptness is still a matter of debate. PIs will run transient paleoclimate simulations using the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) Community Earth System Model (CESM) coupled to an interactive dust model, synthesize paleo-dust and drought records, and test the sensitivity of their results to changes in dust optical properties. 

Intellectual Merit
The proposed research will advance our understanding and knowledge of forcing and feedbacks associated with desert dust in past periods of abrupt climate change, and determine if climate change is more abrupt when dust is an interactive component. Through model-data synthesis, the PIs will analyze if the inclusion of dust climate feedback in paleoclimate simulations bring models into better agreement with observations. Results from the transient paleoclimate simulations will be made available online to facilitate paleoclimate model-data intercomparisons. 

Broader Impacts
The project will establish linkages between the University of Miami, NCAR, and Cornell University through the use of CESM and the participation in the CESM Paleoclimate Working Group. Research activities will be presented at scientific conferences, workshops, and community outreach events, such as the science café (http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/info/seminar-archive/msg01683.html). Knowledge gained from this work will be used to prepare curriculum material for undergraduate and graduate courses taught at the University of Miami. The PIs participate in the Earth Science Women's Network (ESWN), a group that promotes mentoring, support, professional collaborations, and career development with other women working in science and technology. In addition, the PIs participate in the annual RSMAS Women in Science day. This program targets sixth and seventh grade girls, and female scientists from the Rosenstiel School lead hands-on activities in their scientific field to engage the young participants.

por.por_cntn:
Mineral dust alters climate by scattering shortwave radiation from the sun, and absorbing and re-emitting longwave radiation from Earth, resulting in a reduction in the net radiation absorbed at the surface and thus surface cooling. Additionally, it has been shown that dust can impact ocean circulation through changes in buoyancy. We hypothesized that significant changes in the amount of atmospheric dust loading could lead to abrupt changes in past climate. To examine this, we performed a set of global climate model simulations with and without dust as an interactive component of the climate system. We focused on two past periods in which dust emission from North Africa was much different than present: the last Heinrich Event 1 (H1; ~18-15 kyrs before present) and the African Humid Period (~8-6 kyrs before present). During H1, increased ice discharge in the North Atlantic severely reduced the strength of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC). A weaker AMOC is believed to cause cooling throughout the North Atlantic (due to less heat transport), which would then shift the tropical rainbelt southwards into the warmer Southern Hemisphere. Paleoclimate records indicate Heinrich events were marked by severe aridity and dustiness in the northern tropics. Murphy et al. (2014) was the first to use a global climate model to simulate the climate and dust response to a Heinrich event. We found that changes in surface winds had the largest influence on African dust emissions and that enhanced African dust fluxes led to greater ocean cooling and decreased regional precipitation (Murphy et al., 2014). Our simulated Heinrich dust fluxes, were used to estimate the amount of soluble iron deposition to the oceans since the Last Glacial Maximum (Albani et al., 2016), and to examine the impacts on ocean circulation (Murphy et al., under review). We found that enhanced H1 dust loading has a positive amplification on Heinrich events by further cooling and freshening the North Atlantic and enhancing sea-ice coverage. These impacts led to a 20% reduction in ocean circulation. Including both freshwater and H1 dust forcing led to greater cooling in North Atlantic that was more comparable to proxy records (Arienzo et al., 2015; Murphy et al., under review).

During the African Humid Period, North Africa was much wetter and the Saharan desert was replaced by extensive grasslands and lakes. Our climate model simulations for this period show that dust reduces North African precipitation through changes in radiation, and that both land-surface changes and dust changes must be considered to realistically simulate the observed increase in precipitation over North Africa at that time (Murphy et al., in prep.). We also found that regional climate changes due to a wetter and less dusty Africa, coupled with a northward shift in the Westerly Jet, resulted in greater drying and enhanced dust emissions from Middle Eastern deserts during this time (Sharifi et al., accepted).

Additionally, we have examined the connections between atmospheric circulation, clouds and aerosols on modern Atlantic climate variability to determine if these relationships are robust across other time periods (Clement et al., 2016; Bellomo et al., 2016; Murphy et al., 2017; Cane et al., 2017). Three undergraduate (UG) student researchers worked on this project. This opportunity provided them with additional research skills and support to travel to a domestic conference (AGU or AMS). They learned to analyze large data files using both Matlab and the NCAR Command Language (NCL). One student examined the relationship between dust, precipitation and SST as part of his senior thesis. Two of our UG student researchers are currently in graduate school. In addition, this project supported an early career scientist who developed additional skills in model design and development. She participated locally in several career workshops and RSMAS annual Women in Science Day, presented this research at the AGU meeting each year, and co-chaired a paleoclimate session on hydroclimate variability.
